questions.prompt: The determinant of a $2 \times 2$ matrix $\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$ is:
questions.explanation: For a $2 \times 2$ matrix, $\det\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} = ad - bc$.
True. A matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is nonzero. If $\det(A) = 0$, the matrix is singular (not invertible).

questions.prompt: If you swap two rows of a matrix $A$, the determinant:
questions.explanation: Swapping two rows (or two columns) of a matrix changes the sign of the determinant.

questions.prompt: The determinant of the identity matrix $I_n$ is:
questions.explanation: The determinant of any identity matrix is 1: $\det(I_n) = 1$.

questions.prompt: The $(i,j)$-cofactor of matrix $A$ is $C_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j}$ times the ____ of the $(i,j)$ submatrix.
questions.explanation: The cofactor $C_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j}M_{ij}$ where $M_{ij}$ is the determinant of the submatrix obtained by deleting row $i$ and column $j$.

questions.prompt: If you multiply a row of matrix $A$ by scalar $k$, the determinant:
questions.explanation: Multiplying one row by $k$ multiplies the determinant by $k$. Therefore $\det(kA) = k^n\det(A)$ for an $n \times n$ matrix.

questions.prompt: For square matrices $A$ and $B$ of the same size, $\det(AB) = $:
questions.explanation: The determinant of a product equals the product of determinants: $\det(AB) = \det(A)\det(B)$.
True. Since $AA^{-1} = I$, we have $\det(A)\det(A^{-1}) = \det(I) = 1$, so $\det(A^{-1}) = \frac{1}{\det(A)}$.

questions.prompt: Cramer's Rule can be used to solve $Ax = b$ when:
questions.explanation: Cramer's Rule applies when $A$ is square and invertible (i.e., $\det(A) \neq 0$). Each component is $x_i = \frac{\det(A_i)}{\det(A)}$.

questions.prompt: The determinant of a triangular matrix equals the product of its ____ entries.
questions.explanation: For any triangular matrix (upper or lower), the determinant is the product of the diagonal entries.

questions.prompt: The area of the parallelogram formed by vectors $\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}$ and $\begin{bmatrix} c \\ d \end{bmatrix}$ is:
questions.explanation: The area is the absolute value of the determinant: $|\det\begin{bmatrix} a & c \\ b & d \end{bmatrix}| = |ad - bc|$.

questions.prompt: If $A$ has two identical rows, then $\det(A) = $:
questions.explanation: If a matrix has two identical rows (or columns), its determinant is 0 because the rows are linearly dependent.
True. The determinant of a matrix equals the determinant of its transpose: $\det(A^T) = \det(A)$.

questions.prompt: The adjugate (classical adjoint) of matrix $A$ is:
options: The transpose of the cofactor matrix
questions.explanation: The adjugate adj$(A)$ is the transpose of the cofactor matrix. It satisfies $A \cdot \text{adj}(A) = \det(A) \cdot I$.

questions.prompt: If $A$ is $n \times n$ and $\det(A) = d$, then $\det(2A) = $ ____ (in terms of $d$ and $n$).
questions.explanation: Multiplying every entry by 2 multiplies each of the $n$ rows by 2, so $\det(2A) = 2^n\det(A) = 2^n d$.
